1.text:
“I sometimes have a stammer.”
“Are you stupid or something?”

5.text:
“When you breathe like that you sound a
bit like Darth Vader.”

9.text:
“Oh like the King’s Speech?”
As soon as that came out and everyone watched

20.text:
it, it’s just like, “I’m a stammering
expert!”

22.text:
It’s nice that people have something to
relate it to. Because before the King’s

27.text:
Speech it was Gareth Gates wasn’t it?
To be fair, I quite like the scene in the

31.text:
King’s Speech where he just starts swearing
and doesn’t stutter because that’s real

35.text:
life stuff.
It does actually help!

37.text:
He says something like, “Fuckity fuck fuck!”
You know what, that helps a lot though.

47.text:
“Does it stop when you sing?”
Yeah it does. So people ask me, “So why

51.text:
don’t you just sing all the time instead
of speaking?”

53.text:
“Why don’t you just sing it?” I’m
like, well I’m not going to burst into song

58.text:
in the chip shop.
Just imagine speaking to people like this.

65.text:
“People finishing your sentences.”
This is probably, one of the top three which

72.text:
I hate, especially when they get it wrong.
They’re not really helping my stammer. Helping

77.text:
my stammer to me means, for me to say the
words and then get over them.

82.text:
I used to be relieved, but then you get that
feeling of shame afterwards of like, “I’m

87.text:
going to have to say that word again in the
future.”

92.text:
“What happened to you?”
Someone jokingly said, “Did your parents

98.text:
beat you?” and I was like…
I’ve been asked this so many times by people

103.text:
who don’t understand.
I think the majority of people who stutter,

108.text:
it’s just something you grow up with basically.
But there are some examples where people would

115.text:
have had a traumatic incident.
I personally don't think anything happened

120.text:
to me. Unless my parents dropped me and didn’t
tell me. If so, that’s not cool.

129.text:
“Are you stupid or something?”
When they assume that your dumb because of

133.text:
your stutter I think that’s due to a lot
of movies like Water Boy.

137.text:
Because people don’t really think it's a
disability, then it's okay to poke fun at.

146.text:
Whether its Porky Pig or… When fluent people
stutter it’s when they’re nervous. So

152.text:
people sometimes assume you’re nervous or
you’re indecisive. And it can come across

159.text:
in that way but you know exactly what you
want to say.

163.text:
“Is there nothing you can do about that?”
That should get fucking copyrighted. I’ve

171.text:
been asked that a lot of times.
There are things that help, to be fair. So,

177.text:
accepting you stutter, not hiding from it,
letting other people know that you stutter.

182.text:
If you don’t want to do anything about it
then that's fine.

185.text:
Okay, yeah.
No issues with that whatsoever. But if you

188.text:
do, yeah there is help out there.
It’s getting people to understand that it’s

193.text:
a fluid thing. There’s no cure and you’re
always having to work on it.

198.text:
Just put a search in and many kind of therapies
will come up and give them a go.

203.text:
This one for me is a bad one: “Spit it out”.
That’s the worst thing because if people

208.text:
pressure you with time pressure...
It makes it worse.

211.text:
It makes it so much worse.
They don’t even have to say anything, sometimes

214.text:
you just see their attention drift.
The ones I get a lot are either…

220.text:
Oh yeah the clicks.
Or the...

224.text:
When people look away from you. When you can
sort of see them cringing a bit.

232.text:
Yeah.
Being like, “Oh God, I don’t want to be

236.text:
“Don’t you even know your own name?”
It's not that we don’t know our own name,

246.text:
it's just it gets blocked.
Registration would be passed around, and I

249.text:
could always remember kind of rehearsing and
pre-rehearsing, how I would like to say my

255.text:
name.
It is such a big part of you. It is you.

259.text:
Singled me out and asked me why I was talking...
I can’t really remember what I mustered

264.text:
but I did stammer on every other word. And
he imitated right back and gave tit for tat

271.text:
and said, “Nisar, that’s w-w-why y-y-you
sh-sh-sh-ould n-n-never talk in class”.

278.text:
And he got the class in ruptures and I can
remember kind of, burying my head in my non-existing

284.text:
hair and stayed in that posture for maybe
an hour.

289.text:
“Do you feel like your stammer holds you
back?”

294.text:
Yeah, I think I definitely hold back from
doing things like going to drama club or like

299.text:
going for a captaincy in a sports team, because
I didn’t want to do all the motivational

304.text:
talks at half-time.
Certainly, I couldn’t do presentations.

308.text:
Fifteen minute presentation - you're looking
at two hours…

312.text:
There’s just been sometimes where I’m
like, but at the end of the day it’s what

322.text:
makes me me.
The good things I like to think I do in life,

325.text:
have maybe been because of not wanting anyone
else to feel like shit.

329.text:
I think it made me a stronger person it builds
character. So If I have a son and he has a

334.text:
stutter I’d be like fair play.
I see it as a positive challenge. In fact,

338.text:
I’m quite proud to stutter.
It used to hold - it used to stop me from

343.text:
doing everything, now I do what I want.
Yes I stammer so what? It is me so you need
